summaries.body: David Litt, President Obama’s former speechwriter, is to join the humor website “Funny or Die.”

display_asset.caption: Protesters gathering in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in August to demonstrate against the government of Prime Minister Najib Razak. A Malaysian High Court has upheld a government edict declaring yellow shirts that call for a clean government a national security threat.

summaries.body: A Malaysian High Court has upheld a ban on the yellow T-shirts worn by anticorruption protesters. The government had called them a national security threat.
"The Mermaid," a fantasy romantic comedy directed by Stephen Chow, has become China's top-grossing film of all time, taking in $441 million since its release on Feb. 8.

display_asset.caption: The singer Sonny James, who racked up 26 No. 1 country hits in his career.

summaries.body: Sonny James, a singer of the 1960s and '70s with 26 No. 1 country hits to his credit, including "Young Love," has died at 87.

display_asset.caption: Gianandrea Noseda
display_asset.credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times

summaries.body: Gianandrea Noseda, the next music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, has also been named principal guest conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra.

display_asset.caption: Qiaoqiao in a recent photo.

summaries.body: A blind man’s guide dog that had been stolen in Beijing, drawing an unusual amount of attention, has been found with a note asking for forgiveness.

display_asset.credit: Joe Lederer/Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation

summaries.body: It isn't easy making computer-generated characters like Deadpool smile or grimace, and a legal battle has erupted over who owns that technology.

display_asset.caption: Jeh Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, this month. The department said it developed a list of situations where social media accounts could be examined to screen visa applicants and those seeking asylum or refugee status.
display_asset.credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times

summaries.body: Despite technical hurdles and a backlash from rights advocates, the U.S. is working to more closely examine the social media accounts of visa applicants and asylum seekers.

display_asset.caption: On a trip back from Mexico City, the actor Waris Ahluwalia was told that he would not be able to fly until he removed his turban.
display_asset.credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times

summaries.body: After a run-in with a Mexican airline over his wearing a turban, Waris Ahluwalia was greeted like a conquering hero when he finally made it to New York Fashion Week.
Months after being fired from her M.T.A. bus-driving job, Charita Headley took the driver's seat of the M101 she was riding following a dispute with the driver.

display_asset.caption: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., a senator in the Philippines, campaigned for the vice presidency recently in Ilocos Norte Province.
display_asset.credit: Bernie Sipin Dela Cruz/European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: Ferdinand Marcos’s family legacy is undergoing a renaissance as Filipinos prepare for the 30th anniversary of the “People Power” revolution that toppled him.
Bill Gates weighed in on Apple’s clash with the F.B.I. He said that stopping terrorism is in the public interest, but that government needs must be balanced against privacy.

display_asset.caption: Martins Beach in California has been at the center of a battle over private ownership and public access.

summaries.body: A Silicon Valley billionaire has fueled the debate over wealth by buying and closing a popular California beach, then asking for $30 million to open it again.

display_asset.caption: A $10,000 reward has been offered for information leading to a conviction in the death of 13 bald eagles on the Eastern Shore of Maryland.
display_asset.credit: Maryland Natural Resources Police, via Twitter

summaries.body: The death of 13 bald eagles on Maryland's Eastern Shore has led to an investigation into the state's largest such die-off in decades. There were no signs of visible trauma.
Shares of Lumber Liquidators plunged on Monday after the C.D.C. said that people exposed to certain types of the company’s laminate flooring were more likely to get cancer.

display_asset.caption: The primary threads in the floral carpet are yellow — the most common flower is called Desert Gold, which looks like a yellow daisy.

summaries.body: Death Valley, one of the hottest places on Earth, is covered with more than 20 different kinds of desert wildflowers in what visitors are calling a "superbloom."

posts.footer: — Sylvester Stallone on "Creed," for which he is nominated for an Oscar. The New York Times

display_asset.caption: Sylvester Stallone
display_asset.credit: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times

summaries.body: When ‘Creed' came along, I said to myself, ‘I want you to realize you’re the weakest person in this movie.'
A black Labrador named Qiaoqiao, one of about 10 registered guide dogs in Beijing, was stolen from a village outside the Chinese capital, provoking an unusual outcry.
Google Compare, a comparison-shopping site, is being shut down in a move away from selling financial products like insurance and credit cards.

display_asset.caption: Salman Rushdie in New York in August. The fatwa calling for Mr. Rushdie to be killed because of his book “The Satanic Verses” was issued in 1989.

summaries.body: A group of hard-line media organizations in Iran says it has raised $600,000 to augment the bounty for the killing of Salman Rushdie, a British novelist.

display_asset.caption: The Magic Shop studio, which opened in 1988, is prized by musicians for its vintage gear.
display_asset.credit: Christian Hansen for The New York Times

summaries.body: The Magic Shop, a 28-year-old SoHo recording studio favored by Lou Reed, David Bowie and many other famous musicians, will shut its doors next month.

display_asset.caption: Tennessee’s current coach, Holly Warlick, who was a player and a longtime assistant for Summitt, reacted as her team fell behind during a game last month.

summaries.body: The Tennessee women’s basketball team fell out of the Top 25 for the first time since Feb. 17, 1985, ending a streak that no program is within seven seasons of matching.

display_asset.caption: David Oyelowo discussing a scene with the director Ava DuVernay on the set of “Selma.”

summaries.body: Perhaps the Oscars' diversity problem is simply a reflection of Hollywood. A U.S.C. study found an "epidemic of invisibility" for minorities across the film industry.

display_asset.caption: A tribute to Big Ang outside a shop near the Basilica of Regina Pacis in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.
display_asset.credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times

summaries.body: In death, as in life, Angela Raiola, known as Big Ang on “Mob Wives,” drew a crowd. Hundreds attended her funeral, held in Brooklyn on Monday.

display_asset.caption: Andrew Bolton, the curator of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in “The First Monday in May.”

summaries.body: The Tribeca Film Festival will open with a documentary about a 2015 fashion exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that was called "China: Through the Looking Glass."
The day my Megabus caught fire: There was a series of pops, and before we knew it, the bus was in flames. A Times travel writer's first-time trip on a Megabus goes awry.

display_asset.caption: Donald J. Trump spoke approvingly about bullets dipped in pig’s blood at a rally on Friday in North Charleston, S.C.

summaries.body: The sister of a Muslim student killed in North Carolina challenged Donald J. Trump to meet her after he spoke about killing Islamic terrorists with bullets dipped in pigs' blood.

display_asset.caption: Harper Lee appears in a picture on Opus the penguin’s wall in a 1995 cartoon by Berkeley Breathed.

summaries.body: Despite a reclusive reputation, Harper Lee corresponded with Berkeley Breathed, the man behind the comic strip "Bloom County." He shared the letters with The Times.
Jeff Arnold, a writer, apologized for an article in SB Nation that many saw as sympathetic to Daniel Holtzclaw, a former police officer who was convicted of raping women.

display_asset.caption: Traffic in the Wan Chai area of Hong Kong. Demand for auspicious license plates has pushed prices to new heights.

summaries.body: A license plate was sold in Hong Kong for $2.3 million, the highest price ever paid in the city. It carries the number 28, which in Cantonese sounds like a phrase for “easy money.”
